workflow.name: Classify and respond to Facebook Messenger inquiries with GPT-4, Slack and Sheets
workflow.description:
## üìä Description
Streamline Facebook Messenger inbox management with an AI-powered categorization and response system. üí¨‚öôÔ∏è
 This workflow automatically classifies new messages as Lead, Query, or Spam using GPT-4, routes them for approval via Slack, responds on Facebook once approved, and logs all interactions into Google Sheets for tracking. Perfect for support and marketing teams managing high volumes of inbound DMs. üöÄüìà

## What This Template Does
1Ô∏è‚É£ Trigger ‚Äì Runs hourly to fetch new Facebook Page messages. ‚è∞
 2Ô∏è‚É£ Extract & Format ‚Äì Collects sender info, timestamps, and message content for analysis. üìã
 3Ô∏è‚É£ AI Categorization ‚Äì Uses GPT-4 to identify message type (Lead, Query, Spam) and suggest replies. üß†
 4Ô∏è‚É£ Slack Approval Flow ‚Äì Sends categorized leads and queries to Slack for quick team approval. üí¨
 5Ô∏è‚É£ Facebook Response ‚Äì Posts AI-suggested replies back to the original sender once approved. üíå
 6Ô∏è‚É£ Data Logging ‚Äì Records every message, reply, and approval status into Google Sheets for analytics. üìä
 7Ô∏è‚É£ Error Handling ‚Äì Automatically alerts via Slack if the workflow encounters an error. üö®

## Key Benefits
‚úÖ Reduces manual message triage on Facebook Messenger
 ‚úÖ Ensures consistent and professional customer replies
 ‚úÖ Provides full visibility via Google Sheets logs
 ‚úÖ Centralizes team approvals in Slack for faster response times
 ‚úÖ Leverages GPT-4 for accurate categorization and natural replies

## Features
- Hourly Facebook message fetch with Graph API
- GPT-4 powered text classification and reply suggestion
- Slack-based dual approval flow
- Automated Facebook replies post-approval
- Google Sheets logging for all categorized messages
- Built-in error detection and Slack alerting

## Requirements
Facebook Graph API credentials with page message permissions
OpenAI API key for GPT-4 processing
Slack API credentials with chat:write permission
Google Sheets OAuth2 credentials

## Environment Variables:
FACEBOOK_PAGE_ID
GOOGLE_SHEET_ID
GOOGLE_SHEET_NAME
SLACK_CHANNEL_ID

## Target Audience
- Marketing and lead-generation teams using Facebook Pages üì£
- Customer support teams managing Messenger queries üí¨
- Businesses seeking automated lead routing and CRM sync üßæ
- Teams leveraging AI for customer engagement optimization ü§ñ

## Step-by-Step Setup Instructions
1Ô∏è‚É£ Connect Facebook Graph API credentials and set your page ID.
 2Ô∏è‚É£ Add OpenAI API credentials for GPT-4.
 3Ô∏è‚É£ Configure Slack channel ID and credentials.
 4Ô∏è‚É£ Link your Google Sheet for message logging.
 5Ô∏è‚É£ Replace environment variable placeholders with your actual IDs.
 6Ô∏è‚É£ Test the workflow manually before enabling automation.
 7Ô∏è‚É£ Activate the schedule trigger for ongoing hourly execution. ‚úÖ

workflow.name: Classify and Respond to Facebook Messenger Inquiries with GPT-4, Slack, and Google Sheets

parameters.content:
## üìã Classify and Respond to Facebook Messenger Inquiries

### How it works
This automation helps you handle Facebook Page messages automatically with GPT-4.  
Every hour it checks for new messages, extracts the sender‚Äôs details, and sends the content to GPT-4 for classification.  
Messages are categorized as Lead, Query, or Spam.  
Leads and Queries trigger a Slack approval request where your team can approve or reject GPT-4‚Äôs suggested reply.  
Based on that response, the workflow sends an approved or fallback message through Facebook Messenger, logs all activity to Google Sheets, and alerts you of any errors in Slack.

### Setup steps
1. Connect Facebook Graph API, OpenAI, Slack, and Google Sheets credentials.  
2. Set up environment variables: `FACEBOOK_PAGE_ID`, `GOOGLE_SHEET_ID`, `SLACK_CHANNEL_ID`.  
3. Create a Google Sheet with columns for Timestamp, Sender, Category, Summary, AI Reply, and Status.  
4. Adjust the trigger interval if you want faster or slower checks.  
5. Test with one sample message before enabling the full workflow.  
6. Enable error notifications so you‚Äôre informed if anything breaks.

## Data Input & Formatting 

Runs every hour to fetch the latest Facebook Page messages.  
Extracts message text, sender info, and timestamp, then formats the data for GPT-4 classification.

## AI Classification 


Sends the formatted message to GPT-4 for analysis.  
GPT-4 categorizes it as Lead, Query, or Spam, generates a summary, and drafts a suggested reply with confidence scoring.

## Routing & Approvals 

Routes messages based on category.  
Leads and Queries trigger a Slack approval message so your team can approve or reject GPT-4‚Äôs reply before sending.  
Spam is logged automatically without further action.

## Responses & Logging 

Sends approved or fallback replies to users on Messenger.  
All responses, summaries, and approval outcomes are recorded in Google Sheets for tracking and analytics.

## Error Notifications 


If any part of the workflow fails, this section sends a Slack alert with the error message, node name, and timestamp so you can fix it quickly.

nodes.name: Trigger ‚Äì Fetch New Facebook Messages (Every Hour)

parameters.text:
=You received a new message on Facebook Page.

Message: "{{ $json["Message"] }}"
Sender Name: "{{ $json["Senders Name"] }}"
Sender Email: "{{ $json["Sender Email"] }}"
Created Time: "{{ $json["Created Time"] }}"

Classify this message according to the defined categories and provide a short suggested reply if needed.

options.systemMessage:
=You are an AI assistant that analyzes incoming Facebook Page messages and classifies them into one of three categories: Lead, Query, or Spam.

Definitions:
- Lead: A potential customer or business opportunity showing intent to purchase, collaborate, or request a quote.
- Query: A general question, support request, or informational inquiry that doesn‚Äôt indicate a sales intent.
- Spam: Any irrelevant, promotional, scam-like, or inappropriate message.

For each input message, you must:
1. Identify the category.
2. Summarize the message meaning briefly.
3. Suggest an appropriate automated reply if applicable.

Return your answer strictly as a JSON object matching the defined schema.

parameter.name: recipient
parameter.value: ={{ JSON.stringify({ id: $('Format Incoming Message Data').item.json["Senders ID"] }) }}

parameter.name: message
parameter.value: ={{ JSON.stringify({ text: $('AI ‚Äì Classify Message (Lead / Query / Spam)').item.json.output.suggested_reply }) }}

parameter.name: recipient
parameter.value: ={{ JSON.stringify({ id: $('Format Incoming Message Data').item.json["Senders ID"] }) }}

parameter.name: message
parameter.value: ={{ JSON.stringify({ text: "Thank you for your interest! üôè\\n\\nWe\\'re excited to help you. One of our team members will reach out to you shortly with personalized information.\\n\\nIn the meantime, feel free to share any specific questions you have, and we\\'ll make sure to address them!\\n\\nLooking forward to connecting with you!" }) }}

user.name: Rahul Joshi
user.bio: Rahul Joshi is a seasoned technology leader specializing in the n8n automation tool and AI-driven workflow automation. With deep expertise in building open-source workflow automation and self-hosted automation platforms, he helps organizations eliminate manual processes through intelligent n8n ai agent automation solutions.

data.details: In n8n, when a workflow execution fails, it can start another workflow. This second workflow can be any arbitrary workflow on your n8n instance. Use the Error Trigger node as your Trigger in the Error workflow.
